qas.question: What was the general feeling toward Darwin's ideas in France?

answers.text: Darwin's ideas had little impact in France, where any scientists supporting evolutionary ideas opted for a form of Lamarckism

qas.question: What people in what country had embraced the idea of evolution for many years before Darwin published his theory?
Which aspects of evolution theory were thought to be unimportant by many who read Darwin's work?
Which author voiced his displeasure of the morality of Darwin's views in a novel?

context: French-speaking naturalists in several countries showed appreciation of the much modified French translation by Clémence Royer, but <a0_0>Darwin's ideas had little impact in France, where any scientists supporting evolutionary ideas opted for a form of Lamarckism<a0_0/>. <a1_0>The intelligentsia in Russia<a1_0/> had accepted the general phenomenon of evolution for several years before Darwin had published his theory, and scientists were quick to take it into account, although <a2_0>the Malthusian aspects<a2_0/> were felt to be relatively unimportant. The political economy of struggle was criticised as a British stereotype by Karl Marx and by <a3_0>Leo Tolstoy<a3_0/>, who had the character Levin in his novel Anna Karenina voice sharp criticism of the morality of Darwin's views.
